text: Hey Andrew. I hear you on the work-life balance. It was a concern for me as well when I was in school and getting closer to graduating.

My answer to that is that it really differs per studio and per person. It can vary greatly from company to company how much overtime and extra effort they expect you to spend beyond the regular 9-5 hours.
Sometimes even within a studio it can vary depending on the project.

And sometimes it depends on the people that work there. I had one studio that didn't really condone or want overtime on paper, but there was one guy in authority that promoted the (in my opinion) outdated notion that if you didn't work overtime you couldn't be good, which is simply not true.

On an individual basis it can also depend on yourself. Some people are more driven than others and will stay late simply because they enjoy the work, and that's fine. However, if that doesn't float your boat and you want to do your hours and then go home that is something you very much have a right to.
For me personally, I had to find the right work-life balance for me, and you'll need to do the same when you go into the industry.

I was and still am on the driven side of the spectrum, but I've learned a few things about what I personally need over the years. In uni I used to basically work non-stop, between 60 to 100 hours in the busier weeks. I graduated after 4 years never really taking a break. I would work during a lot of my breaks too to keep learning or to get ahead, aside from the summer vacation period. After graduating I went straight into a job where eventually I spent similar hours on a big project, between 60 and 80 hours. Before that project, it was between 40 and 60. It was a big animation project so it was a lot of fun, but at the same time very taxing on both my body and my mind. There were a number of external and personal factors as well that contributed heavily, but eventually, after 6 years of doing almost nothing but working, I burned out (no shit, you're probably thinking!). Anyway, burnout is _not_ fun, and it took me a few years to get back to where I was. It was around that time that the VFX crash happened in Hollywood as well if you're familiar with that, and that combined with the burnout made me change my attitude on overtime quite drastically.

I realized how important it was to have a work-life balance, even if you don't feel you need the break, and with the VFX crash, I kind of stopped doing it out of principle, as well. Rights for studios and more so artists are still very poorly protected, and not all studios will protect their artists' rights to their own time, so in a lot of cases I try to remember that I'm contractually not obligated to work extra hours, and try to protect my own time if the company asks it of me. And it's true that they might let me go for it, but I realized that if that's how they treat their people then I don't really want to work with them.

There's an increasing number of studios and artists that do respect people's personal time, so the notion of having to do overtime simply because that's the industry you're a part of is becoming a little old fashioned.

Which is not to say I never do overtime. I do, definitely. Sometimes projects hit crunch time and you just wanna put in that extra time to make it better, or you have a deadline you need to hit, and you simply haven't finished your work, which is sometimes on you, so you need to put in some extra hours to make sure it's finished.

I say 'sometimes' because one thing to realize is that some companies are better at planning than others. I learned this after going to Blue-Zoo not long after my burnout. It was my first full-time animation job. I'd been working as a generalist up until that point, but I was kind of shocked to find that they didn't really facilitate overtime. It was possible, for sure, but unless someone had keys you had to be out of the building by 7 or 8 because the cleaners would come and lock up the building, and yet for the project I was on all the work was getting finished just fine, because they knew from the start how to plan and budget. That won't always be the case, and I've had some companies where schedules were all over the place, corners were cut, and deadlines simply weren't feasible, but that's *their* mistake. You can try and help them with it, but you have to remember that their planning, or lack thereof, is not your responsibility, even if they try to make it so.
A very long story, sorry, but it depends on a lot of variables as you can see! I hope it gives you some insight, nonetheless.
